review_title: World-changer that adds great meaning to my work and life
pros:
Opportunity to help change history, make a difference in the world as part of the largest, most effective organization battling modern slavery.
Amazing colleagues, many of whom took demotions and/or pay cuts from brilliant careers elsewhere to come to IJM.
Integration of faith and work beyond any church or faith-based organization I've ever seen (and I've seen quite a few).
cons:
Classic growing pains as IJM "graduates" to > $50M annual revenue, the big hurdle few INGOs navigate well.  Lots of change; change management is not IJM's strength.
Daily exposure to darkness and evil, the everyday violence perpetrated upon the poor and oppressed takes its toll on your heart.  We can't rescue every victim, the fight to end impunity is long and hard, but miracles ARE happening and it's totally worth it to me to know that I play a small part in rescue and restoration of real people, and transformation of broken public justice systems so fewer real people will be at risk.
So much to do, so few resources.  Like all non-profits, IJM has to stretch donor dollars to the max.  The nature of the mission is so compelling, it's easy to work longer hours than managers are even asking for, longer hours than healthy.

IJM’s Theory of Change is doing wonders in transforming communities around the world and it’s the privilege of a lifetime getting to be a part of it.
cons:
Unfortunately, the organization is notorious for promoting unqualified and incompetent leaders into positions of authority because they “play the game” and fit well into the “good ole boys club”. If you’re starting your career as an Intern, this is the place to be. Unfortunately, if you’re coming in with a significant amount of real world experience in your field (like me), you’ll find that opportunities for growth are incredibly limited.

Favoritism is rampant and if you’re a woman / person of color, your chances of being promoted to leadership are even more diminished.

review_title: Great Mission, Not So Great Organization
pros: The mission is amazing, and, some of the people you work with are amazing.
cons: As a new staff member, it can be quite difficult to find your place. One soon realizes that it's a "good ole boy" environment, with a few women who've been allowed to "play with the boys" for the long-haul. Quite a number of people have been let go for no apparent reason. Generally, it's not because of poor performance; often more of a matter of constantly changing strategic alignment. Some departures have been handled quite poorly and offensively--poor timing, lack of clear communication, and not always "above board" or with transparency. For some, very little to no recognition of time served, beyond the transactional issues you would expect to be addressed through HR. Many have felt like they were a pebble who made quite an impact, but were easily let go, dismissed, and forgotten. Some pretty amazing people in top positions have left because they just couldn't work with an organization that doesn't care more for it's people. Many of these issues are systemic at various levels, but the buck stops with senior leadership--CEO, president, and vice presidents.

review_title: Fantastic at changing the world (and promoting it), not so great at employee recognition.

pros: I have worked at IJM for almost 11 years and I am more excited about our mission that ever before.  I worked in the pubic and private sector before this job and I have never come across such an extraordinary group of people committed to excellent service to the poorest with deep joy and fearlessness.  Anyone who is seeking to use their skills to make an impact in the world (and you yourself be changed for the better in the process) should consider coming to join us.
cons: IJM is a fast growth organization which means people who come here should be comfortable with, even enjoy / thrive in, change.  You will never be stagnant or bored here, but during certain seasons the amount of change needed, to keep up with our growth, can be quite daunting.  No organization will be able to predict with 100% accuracy what the future will hold and IJM has been slow at times to catch up with its growth which has caused some rising fatigue and falling agility, but management is keenly attuned to the need and we've never been better positioned for continual growth and health.

review_title: It was the best of times...and the worst of times
pros: IJMs mission is a do-gooder dream come true and the work in the field is compelling. You get to work alongside many others who are passionate about the same things, and who desire relationships with one another that extend beyond just work - many of my closest friendships were formed here. Some of the best leaders in the world are here (but sadly some of the most challenging, as well).
cons: The organization is in the midst of (at least) the 4th in a series of reorganizations that have not resulted in any sustained positive improvement for the way that the organization functions. The result for many staff members current and former has been burn out, disillusionment and frustration with management and leadership - and a continued concern that the organization does not have what it needs to right the ship. Poor leaders are allowed to stay in positions, even with overwhelming evidence that they are harmful to their teams and the culture.

review_title: Growing Pains Are a Bigger Problem because of Feckless Leadership
pros: The mission of IJM is amazing, and there are so many people there whose commitment is unmatched. IJM attracts new, high caliber, talent in roles throughout the organization. People, despite the frustrations with leadership, are committed to the mission and the organization, and work very hard toward success.
cons: There is an 'in' group of people who find themselves in leadership, and aren't held accountable for results. There are so many people at IJM who have vast experience in their vield, but are routinely ignored because of the clique of friends in senior leadership. The organization missed an opportunity to bring in new and innovative leadership, with experience in building a global organization. Instead, they chose to promote a leader from within. The domino effect of which is that the same clique of friends continues to get promoted into positions of leadership, despite no experience to warrant those positions. In the past year, multiple promotions have been given to people based on friendship instead of performance.

pros:
The same things that attracted me to work at IJM are still true every day: the vision is inspiring, the accomplishments are rewarding, the colleagues are hilarious and brilliant, and the other benefits (pay, spiritual formation, community) are fantastic. 

Even on the days when my job can feel tedious or frustrating, we get to see the real impact of our work: children and families are rescued from slavery and violence, and we're creating massive change to better protect the poor long-term. I've gotten great experience as a young professional to grow and develop.
cons:
IJM has gone through a lot of growing pains over the last few years as we transition from a small organization to a medium one. It's meant a lot of shifting priorities and structures, which has felt very painful at times. Within the last year, though, leaders have done an intentional job of communicating clearly and helping manage change to keep us on track.

In the day-to-day, I think we struggle with many of the same challenges of other non-profits: keeping things lean enough to be cost-effective while not having enough staff and resources to always innovate the ways we'd like. Our work in the field is very cutting edge, but we're still learning how to do that in our U.S. office and it can feel frustrating for some people coming from resource-rich corporate backgrounds.

pros: I started at IJM in an entry-level position and can hardly believe the opportunities I have had to grow and use my skills in my work here. In particular, it's remarkable to me how much IJM's leadership invests in the younger staff. The leaders are personable and encouraging, and they have challenged and mentored me, helping me grow professionally and personally. At all levels of the organization, the people who work here are amazing, driven, fun people; I've met some of my best friends in my colleagues.
cons: IJM is growing fast. We are also consistently learning from our work and adapting in order to serve our clients better. As such, there has been a good bit of change in the past few years, which I think has been seen as a bad thing. But change can actually be a GREAT thing if it means you're adapting and working smarter. As someone else wrote in a previous review, if stasis is not your thing, then you might find IJM's adaptations stressful.

pros: The organization is a very mission-focused group of professionals looking to protect the poor from violence in the developing world.  There is a also huge push for spiritual formation which has been central to improving my professional and spiritual lives.  The caliber of people is very high too.  To date, I haven't seen anyone who hasn't been pulling their weight.
cons: Caveat:  every organization has their issues.  IJM is no exception to this rule.  The organization isn't exactly diverse.  The majority of employees (admin assistants, program managers, etc) seem to be white, females under the age of 30.  And the majority of the leadership are old white males.  There also seems to be a perception of a good-ole-boy system with only those in the inner circle being promoted.  The organization is also run by lawyers which means there's plenty of ego to go around.

pros: My coworkers are my favorite part of my job. I've been at IJM for over 4 years now and have continued to build great friendships with my colleagues no matter what team I'm on. IJM attracts some of the most driven, hard working, brilliant talent and it is an honor to work with them. Also, I don't think you can beat the mission if you are passionate about social justice issues. IJM is the leader in many of their casework areas and always trying to find new ways to fight violence against the poor.
cons: IJM has grown a lot in their casework and workforce over the last few years and I think the growing pains have hit the HQ office hard. I don't think the current infrastructure is big enough or strong enough to support the new initiatives and goals of the organization. I cannot remember the last time I worked a 40 hour week and from what I gather, I'm not alone. I know leadership is working to hire new, strategic positions but it's been a slow process and I think many people have experienced burnout waiting for the environment to change.

pros: The work and the mission is incredibly meaningful and rewarding.  IJM attracts high caliber people and colleagues are not just coworkers, but also friends.  The spiritual practices and the emphasis on community is unique and fosters both personal growth and an authentic community of people working toward a mission together.  The work is challenging and has allowed me to grow professionally.  IJM is growing quickly which has created more opportunities to move up within the organization than there used to be.
cons: IJM attracts very motivated and dedicated employees, which tends to exacerbate an environment of performance at the expense of work/life balance.  The onus is definitely on individuals to initiate and set boundaries.  Because IJM is growing quickly, there are definite growing pains.  Major leadership changes in the last year and multiple department re-organizations has been a significant challenge, but leadership is taking steps to address the issues.

review_title: IJM is what it appears to be
pros:
- Awesome mission that is actually transforming the world; meaningful work experience; feeling of making a difference 
- Atmosphere of professionalism and excellence. The people who work here are competent, kind, smart, driven people -- the kind of people you want to have on your team and who make working in an office a positive experience.
- Integrity among staff and leadership. So far I have not seen anything that wasn't "above board." 
- Decent benefits and compensation for a non-profit. Managers seem to want to work with their staff to create a flexible and positive working environment
cons:
- The organization seems to be experiencing some growing pains as it gets larger. Changes in leadership and organizational structure have led to some confusion and lack of clarity among staff, but it seems like management is working hard to address this 
- Maintaining a healthy work/life balance is encouraged by leadership and possible to do but often hard to practice unless you are good at setting boundaries.

pros: Very compelling and focused mission. Amazingly smart, talented and fun colleagues. Holistic professional and leadership development including the most robust spiritual formation environment I've ever experienced. Over an almost three-decade career spanning three different large organizations, I can unreservedly say that IJM is the best place I've ever worked.
cons: Through my time at IJM, change has been constant. There is no stasis. Over the last few years in particular, different divisions have met the challenge of change with differing levels of management expertise. As a result, some parts of the organization have experienced more pain than others. If you prefer stasis, IJM may not be for you.

pros: Working at IJM means that every day you can leave work knowing that you made a tangible difference in the world. You are privileged to work with like-minded colleagues who care about the mission, our clients and each other. IJM also trusts its employees to do their work and make business decisions based on data and results. The culture at IJM is encouraging and caring.
cons: Because of the type of employee at IJM attracts and the compelling mission we are undertaking, it can lead to periods of high work volume. In my experience, when you have a conversation about work/life balance with your manager it is well received and steps are taken to mitigate it, but there is a cultural push to strive that needs to be fought against.

pros: The mission is great and challenging.  The people are motivated and passionate. The overall culture is great.  Leadership cares about the staff, their spiritual health and life outside of work. The CEO is often encouraging us to be kind and caring toward one another in our work. Leadership communicates well with the staff, especially while dealing with a lot of recent transition and restructuring.
cons: IJM has been growing and is scaling up a number of areas to support an even larger organization, not for the sake of size but for the sake of protecting more people from violence by ending slavery and human trafficking and transforming justice systems globally. Growth means that things change, and sometimes they change significantly and often. A new ERP system is in the works and will bring more changes to processes and roles.  You need to be comfortable with change.

review_title: Amazing Organization in the midst of major transitions
pros: IJM is a great place to work. My colleagues are some of the brightest, fun, passionate people I know. Strategy teams are always looking for improvement and planning for the future. They are implementing systems that most non-profits haven't considered. The mission is something I am proud of and can support.
cons: Because IJM is growing so fast, I think some employees feel that their great efforts are not getting acknowledged. I haven't personally experienced this but I imagine some of the negative reviews on here are derived from those feelings. The organization continually scores low on professional development and upward mobility but I know that they see this as a problem and are working to structure the organization differently to improve this.

pros:
I am giving IJM 5/5 stars. I am a former employee who was laid off within the last 3 months. I would never write a review to undermine anyone else's experience (recent 1 star reviews) but I did want to provide a different perspective. I have worked in ministry for over 20 years and I can say unequivocally that IJM is in the top 1% of employers to work for. Actually, from my perspective, I think that is the reason for the recent negative reviews is because IJM has never faced transitions like most ministries have. And when you are in the top 1% of employers, and go through a transition, it can be a bit jarring. But I can tell you that even through these transitions, in my opinion, IJM is still in the top 1-2% of employers to work for, ESPECIALLY as it relates to ministry. I have seen over and over and over again discrimination of women in ministry, (prior to my work at IJM), it is rampant. When I started at IJM, I had my breath taken away when I saw how they uphold the dignity of each individual--where men and women are considered equal and have the exact same opportunities professionally. 
In over 22 years of ministry work, I have been laid off twice. During the first layoff in 2008, I had a 30 second meeting, was given a slip of paper and in 90 seconds had my laptop and phone retrieved and was ushered out. No severance, nothing. I had to call my family from the land line at work to tell them I had gotten laid off and that my number was no longer good. That is what you get with many ministries. They did what was required, nothing more. I like to size up someone as far as their character based on three things 1) Proven character- show me what you have done over a long period of time 2) Above and Beyond character- show me how you have exceeded what was required 3) Hidden character (in a good way)-show me something you have done consistently, going and above and beyond, that you haven’t told anyone about, i.e. “don’t let your left hand know what your right hand is doing.” Matthew 6:3. An example of this would be someone who has tithed for 20 years, but instead of giving 10% they have given 30%, and they have never told anyone about it. The example doesn’t have to be financial, it can be relational etc., but to me these three things are a mark of deep, deep integrity. With IJM, their kindness to me through the layoff mirrored the character of Christ in its utter and complete generosity. So much so, I had my breath taken away yet again, especially given my prior experience. Why would IJM do something like that for someone, when it is not required, when it is above and beyond and most importantly, when no one would find out about it. I’ll tell you why, because the character of IJM is marked by utter generosity, not only financially but in prayer, in preferring others and in service to the Lord. It is this generosity that made their treatment of me a given. I just wanted to share this with you, who are thinking about employment at IJM. I could not recommend it more highly.
cons: The system is asking me for cons. I can't think of any. In fact, something I didn't include above, that is very special is how each team at IJM bonds and how they really care for each other. In fact, since the layoff my team has been praying for me, that is very special and hard to find.

pros: Leadership makes a concerted effort to keep the entire organization involved in the mission. Daily briefings truly make the lowest level employees feel like they are contributing to saving lives and ending poverty.
cons: It is a religious organization and it is easy to see how placing that at the center of the company limits the scope of the mission. The model relies upon pre-existing Christian communities within areas of operation to serve as volunteers, host fellows and interns, and act as liaisons to the wider community. This is not to say that IJM will not work to say Muslim or Buddhist or Hindu victims, but the organization's preference for Christian employees and refusal to work where there is not a large Christian community does scream irridentism.

As I left, the tide seemed to be moving towards using people as a means to an end, rather than truly valuing individuals.  While peers were amazing, some of the leadership didn't want any diversity of thought.

review_title: Compelling mission, stuffy culture, haphazard project & change mgmt
pros: Compelling mission with great benefits, and better than average pay for an NGO
cons:
Staff are almost always very stressed because there's an expectation to constantly bite off more than can be chewed due to the urgency of IJM's very compelling mission. As a result projects and change are poorly managed, lacking some very basic standard operating procedures, resulting in even more stress. IJM moves so quickly that it virtually never pauses to reflect, analyze, and learn. Lessons are not absorbed into the organization's knowledge & culture. 

IJM seems fairly typical of DC culture - the expectation to be straight-laced and type-A. Add to that the slightly conservative bent of it being a christian organization and the requirements to dress in business formal clothing every day, the result is a suffocating company culture. Only work here if this sounds attractive to you. 

IJM has grown very rapidly in recent years. As a result, their back-office operations have had tremendous growing pains, causing very high leadership turnover and chronically unfilled positions. Things feel constantly in-flux at IJM which takes its toll on everyone. If you interview at IJM, specifically in business or people operations,  demand honest answers about leadership and management turnover before accepting an offer. 

IJM has approached a lot of these problems by just hiring more staff, hoping that more employees will plug the gaps in missing or inconsistent back-office processes. Unfortunately, this not only makes back-office processes more disjointed; it also means that a staff's job description is only accurate for the duration of the quick-fix project they were hired to work on, if ever. As a result, there is no clear career path for most staff. 

Even though IJM does commit a great deal of resources towards spiritual formation, quarterly retreats, daily prayer and sincerely pursues spiritual well-being in its work, I find that too often this results in dismissing pressing business operations problems with a "Just turn it over to the Lord," attitude, or outright hostility at being told where things need to improve.  Comments on how to improve things disappear into the leadership void. 

It pains me to say, because the mission of IJM is so important, but my overall experience with IJM was very negative.

review_title: Riding on successes of the past; Leadership lost its humility

review_title: Measurable, impactful work but significant diversity and inclusion issues in the workplace
pros: IJM truly does pursue excellence and teams work hard to move in the right direction with process and strategy, starting to engage further on pressing issues like diversity and inclusion. There are members of leadership that care deeply about the health of the organization and take monitoring and evaluation, listening and learning activities very seriously. Self-care is still championed in the midst of a tough and challenging weight of work, and coworkers are encouraging and very amicable.
cons: Though granted positive change doesn't happen overnight, IJM is behind. Pulling much of their funds from a white evangelical base, leaning on their "Christian identity" hurts the impact of their work, leveraging donors with white savior complexes while trying to be an objective, justice-focused global organization. Though IJM's work overseas is admirable and effective, and each office is decentralized and mainly run by Host Country Nationals, the North America office is still the driving force of funds and struggles to find its place within the context of US politics and social justice issues. If you're white, IJM North America will most likely be an enjoyable experience, but it will soon leave a bad taste in the mouth when seeing how microaggressions towards BIPOC team members have gone ignored in the past. IJM is committed to change, and they are going in the right direction. If called out now, I have no doubts leadership will hold themselves accountable. However, that does not excuse the lack of diversity and the warped perspective within the organization. There is a bit of irony when an organization that claims to be a bold advocate of human rights, globally, specifically combating issues like police abuse of power, plays it safe, in a somewhat cautious way on these same issues in the North America context. IJM's work overseas is measurable and impactful. Teams are driven, and though growth within the organization can be difficult, its a good place to work. IJM North America, however, just isn't that diverse, and up to this point, not that inclusive. I bet five years down the line it will be better. I suppose, if you're white, and on leadership's "good side", it would feel worth the wait.

review_title: Not what it used to be...
pros: The organization has a great mission and is doing good work around the world. The spiritual component is also really unique from daily spiritual rhythms like corporate prayer and stillness to quarterly prayer retreats. There is somewhat of a “family” feel among the staff, especially after you’ve worked there for a while. Real relationships are built and many people are close friends outside of work.
cons: -Constant change and transition over the past few years including multiple major reorganizations and nearly half of the senior leadership team leaving in the past 12 months (some voluntary, some not). Unfortunately despite all of the change, there has been little improvement and the ongoing change has been frustrating and tiring for staff.  -Poor work/life balance. This is a widespread issue due to a combination of lack of prioritization by leadership and the “type A” nature of most staff who are driven and motivated by the mission. Management says they value work/life balance, but their actions don’t match their words. Instead of addressing workload issues and prioritizing well, they put the burden on entry and mid-level staff to figure it out on their own. Even worse, spiritual and emotional manipulation is used to make staff feel ashamed for complaining about workload, and at times for working too much. Because of this, burnout is rampant and turnover is high. –Poor leadership that is highly political and lacks experience leading an organization of IJM’s growing size. Most leaders don’t respond well to feedback and the executive office fails to communicate effectively. Even worse, IJM’s “Christian” value no longer seems to be important to the organization. People are treated poorly, dishonesty is frequent and generally there is a sense that the ends justify the means in the way you do your work. -Many basic systems and processes are ineffective and inefficient. If you value working at a place that is well organized and efficient, you will find many of IJM’s policies and processes to be unclear and cumbersome.
